The Act may be cited as the "America's Border Security Act of 2007" and includes provisions related to technological assets. The "America's Border Security Act of 2007" mandates increased use of Department of Defense equipment like unmanned aerial vehicles and radars to aid in surveillance at U.S. borders to curb illegal immigration. A report detailing current equipment usage must be submitted to Congress within 6 months of the Act's enactment. The Act mandates increased use of Department of Defense equipment for border surveillance to curb illegal immigration. A report on current equipment usage must be submitted to Congress within 6 months. The Secretary of Homeland Security will conduct a pilot program using unmanned aerial vehicles for border surveillance along the Canada-US border. This does not affect the prohibition on using Army or Air Force for posse comitatus. The Secretary of Homeland Security will conduct a pilot program using unmanned aerial vehicles for border surveillance along the Canada-US border. This does not affect the prohibition on using Army or Air Force for posse comitatus. Authorization of appropriations is provided for fiscal years 2008 through 2012. SEC. 3. INFRASTRUCTURE.

The Secretary of Homeland Security will construct roads, acquire barriers, and facilities for border control. Quarterly progress reports will be submitted to Congress. Appropriations are authorized for fiscal years 2008 through 2012.

SEC. 4. PORTS OF ENTRY. SEC. 4. PORTS OF ENTRY. The Secretary of Homeland Security is authorized to construct additional ports of entry along the international land borders of the United States and make necessary improvements to existing ports of entry. SEC. 5. SECURE COMMUNICATION. The Secretary of Homeland Security will develop a plan to enhance satellite communication for Border Patrol agents and other agencies for clear and secure communication. SEC. 6. UNMANNED AERIAL VEHICLES. The Secretary of Homeland Security is required to acquire and maintain at least 5 unmanned aerial vehicles and related equipment for patrolling the US international borders. This includes additional sensors, critical spares, satellite command and control, and other necessary operational support equipment. Appropriations are authorized for fiscal years 2008 and 2009 to carry out this mandate, with funds remaining available until expended. SEC. 7. SURVEILLANCE TECHNOLOGIES PROGRAMS. The Secretary of Homeland Security is required to develop and implement an aerial surveillance program using unmanned aerial vehicles to enhance border security with Canada and Mexico, ensuring continuous monitoring of each mile of the international borders. The Secretary of Homeland Security is tasked with developing an aerial surveillance program using unmanned aerial vehicles to monitor the international borders with Canada and Mexico. This program aims to assess and utilize aerial surveillance technologies to address border threats effectively. The aerial surveillance program developed by the Secretary of Homeland Security aims to utilize technologies to address border threats effectively. This includes consulting with the Secretary of Defense and the Administrator of the Federal Aviation Administration for deployment, safety, airspace coordination, and regulation. The program will incorporate a variety of aerial surveillance technologies in different topographies. The program developed by the Secretary of Homeland Security includes the use of various aerial surveillance technologies in different topographies, including populated and unpopulated areas near the US international border. The program aims to evaluate the significance, cost, and effectiveness of these technologies for border security. The Secretary of Homeland Security may continue using aerial surveillance technologies for border security while assessing their effectiveness. A report to Congress is required within 180 days. The Secretary of Homeland Security can continue using aerial surveillance technologies for border security and must submit a report to Congress within 180 days, including program details and recommendations for improvement. Authorization of appropriations is also provided. The Secretary of Homeland Security is required to establish a program for border surveillance using various technologies to achieve operational control and create a "virtual fence" along international borders. Authorization of appropriations is provided for this program. The Integrated and Automated Surveillance Program aims to use vehicles, cameras, sensors, satellites, and radar to establish a "virtual fence" along US international borders for border security. The program components focus on integrating and automating technologies for cohesive functioning. The Integrated and Automated Surveillance Program ensures that technologies are integrated and function cohesively in an automated fashion, with cameras not requiring manual operation and able to pan and tilt in response to sensor alerts. Camera views are not fixed, surveillance videos can be viewed at designated centers, and a standard process is used for data collection and cataloging. The Integrated and Automated Surveillance Program ensures cameras can pan and tilt in response to alerts, with views not fixed. Surveillance videos can be viewed at designated centers, and a standard process is used for data collection and cataloging. Future technology investments can be integrated with existing systems, and performance measures are developed to evaluate program effectiveness in detecting illegal intrusions along US borders. The Integrated and Automated Surveillance Program aims to evaluate performance measures, streamline site selection processes, and develop standards for shared use of surveillance technology infrastructure. The Integrated and Automated Surveillance Program aims to develop standards for shared use of surveillance technology infrastructure, including remote and mobile platforms to enhance border security. The Secretary of Homeland Security must report to Congress on the Program's implementation within one year. The Secretary of Homeland Security must report to Congress on the Integrated and Automated Surveillance Program within one year of implementation, including recommendations for enhancement. Standards will be developed to evaluate contractors providing goods or services for the program. Homeland Security will establish standards to assess contractor performance for the Integrated and Automated Surveillance Program. The Inspector General will review contracts over $5,000,000 to ensure compliance with cost requirements, performance objectives, and schedules. The Inspector General will review contracts over $5,000,000 to ensure compliance with cost requirements, performance objectives, program milestones, and schedules. Reports of findings will be submitted to the Secretary of Homeland Security and relevant committees within 30 days. The Secretary will submit a report to the Senate and House Committees on Homeland Security regarding findings and actions taken in response. Authorization of appropriations is provided for necessary funds. SEC. 8. HIRING AND TRAINING OF BORDER AND TRANSPORTATION SECURITY PERSONNEL. During fiscal year 2008, the Secretary of Homeland Security is required to increase the number of full-time agents and support staff in the Bureau of Immigration and Customs Enforcement by 400, and in the Bureau of Customs and Border Protection by 600. The Secretary is authorized to waive any limitation on personnel numbers to meet these requirements. Training must also be provided for these personnel. The Secretary of Homeland Security is authorized to increase the number of full-time agents and support staff in the Bureau of Customs and Border Protection by 600. Additionally, appropriate training must be provided to ensure proficiency levels and utilization of new technologies for border protection. SEC. 9. NATIONAL BORDER SECURITY PLAN. The Secretary of Homeland Security must prepare and submit a National Border Security Plan to Congress by January 31 each year. The plan includes a vulnerability assessment of each port of entry on the northern and southern borders, with consultation from various law enforcement agencies and private entities involved in international trade. Port security coordinators may be established at these entry points. The National Border Security Plan requires a vulnerability assessment of each port of entry on the northern and southern borders. Port security coordinators may be established to assist with assessments and plan preparation.
